So if there are 3 terms: A,B,C and a relation: XX with the following arrangement A--XX-->B, and C a stray term. If XX is selected as a Hierarchy, term A will appear as a root node.

section.name: Built-in Relations
section.note: Specify the relations to use for built-in support of synonyms and abbreviations. Relations with -- before the name are not currently active and will not produce any results. "Synonym" and "Abbreviation" are the default values, but any relation can be used.

field.note: Default relation is used for drag-and-drop behaviour in the asset map. When one term is linked to another, the relation chosen here will be used, except when the link is created to the Thesaurus itself - when term becomes a top-level term.
To add a relation, tick a box in front of the text field. Relation without a name is a valid relation.

To delete a relation, select a box near that relation's name. NOTE: When relations are deleted, all links between terms using those relations are deleted. If you delete ALL relations, you will be left with a thesaurus where terms are not linked.

section.name: Reflections

field.note: When this is disabled, reflection integrity will not be enforced when linking and unlinking terms.

section.note: For ANSI compliance relations must be reciprocal - i.e. if A relates to B using a NT relation, B must relate to A using some relation as well, usually this relation is named BT. Even though relations remain unidirectional in the Thesaurus, here you can specify the reciprocal relation pairs. The purpose of this section is to enforce a reciprocal link to be created automatically. When enabled, if the map says that relation XX has a reciprocal YY, if term A is linked under term B using relation XX, term B will automaticallyl linked under A using YY relation. So B--XX-->A => A--YY-->B. If you make a relation XX reflect itself, it means that creation of B--XX-->A will also result in A--XX-->B.
